examples.en: We split the pasta between two people.
examples.ja: パスタを二人で分ける。

examples.en: Let's separate university notebooks from your private notebooks.
examples.ja: 大学用のノートとプライベートのノートを分けよう。

examples.en: If you split the pizza, could you give me the bigger half?
examples.ja: ピザを半分に分けるなら、大きい方を下さい。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う (in this case る) sound, you know this word is a verb. One of the kanji meanings is <kanji>divide</kanji>, which makes this <vocabulary>to divide something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to separate something</vocabulary>. Depending on the context, it can also mean <vocabulary>to share</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to classify</vocabulary>.

Be careful not to confuse this with 分かる, a similar word with a different meaning. Think of it this way: You "separate" what you care (ける) about from everything else. You want to separate those special things you care about from all the other things you don't care about.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already know this reading from 分かる, but here’s a mnemonic in case you forgot:

Whenever you need <vocabulary>to divide something</vocabulary>, you can’t help screaming "<reading>WAAAAAAAAAHHHH</reading>" (わ). You hate having to divide things, or people, so you always end up screaming "WAAAAAAAAAHHHH" in agony.

examples.en: That man is Yamada's older brother.
examples.ja: あの男の人が、山田さんのお兄さんです。

examples.en: My older brother is big and he also has a masculine demeanor.
examples.ja: 私のお兄さんは体が大きくて、仕草も男の子らしいです。

examples.en: Hey there! Your shirt has some blood on it!
examples.ja: ちょっと、そこのお兄さん！シャツに血がついてますよ！

meaning_mnemonic: This word starts with an お to make it more polite. Then it has the kanji <kanji>兄</kanji> which you already know. Lastly, it has さん which is an honorific to elevate people and be polite. This is basically the formal way of saying <vocabulary>older brother</vocabulary> (versus plain old 兄). It can also be used to refer to a <vocabulary>guy</vocabulary> that you don't know who has a youthful appearance.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for this one is pretty tricky, and I'd consider it an exception. To remember it, you have to learn the 兄 part, and everything else will fall into place. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

Your (kind) <vocabulary>older brother</vocabulary> pushes you down on the ground. You stand up and look at your <reading>knee</reading> (にい), which is all bloody. "Why'd you do that to my knee!?" you ask. "You're supposed to be a nice older brother, that's why I call you お兄さん!"

examples.en: I'll swap shifts with Jenny.
examples.ja: ジェニーとシフトを代わる。

examples.en: If you don't mind, can I take your place?
examples.ja: もしよければ、代わりましょうか。

examples.en: This boy is a genius to replace Steve Jobs.
examples.ja: この少年はスティーブ・ジョブズに代わる天才です。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>substitute</kanji>, and the verb 代わる means <vocabulary>to substitute for</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to take over for</vocabulary>. Use it when one player substitutes for another in sports, for example, or when someone takes over for you at work. 

代わる is usually intransitive, but sometimes it can be transitive and take a direct object. Kind of like "to take over" in English — someone can take over your shift (transitive), or just take over for you (intransitive).
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember the か part:

You need something <vocabulary>to substitute for</vocabulary> your <reading>car</reading> (か). It's getting repaired, so you can't use it now. I guess you can substitute your bike for your car?

examples.en: I have no thought of going to college.
examples.ja: 大学に入学する考えはありません。

examples.en: Is that your own thought? Or is it your husband's thought?
examples.ja: それは自分の考えですか？それともご主人の考えですか？

examples.en: Can I buy your thoughts for 100 yen?
examples.ja: あなたの考えを百円で買わせてもらえませんか？

meaning_mnemonic: This is a noun version of <kanji>think</kanji>. What is "a think"? It's a <vocabulary>thought</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading with 考える, just cut off the る!

examples.en: People have their own way of thinking.
examples.ja: 考え方は、人それぞれです。

examples.en: My ex and I had the same way of thinking.
examples.ja: 元パートナーと私は、考え方が同じだった。

examples.en: Do you really think that you can become a hero of Japanese society with that way of thinking?
examples.ja: その考え方で、日本社会のヒーローになれるとでも本当に思ってるんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>think</kanji> <kanji>way</kanji> is really the way someone thinks. That's why this word means <vocabulary>way of thinking</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This uses the kun'yomi readings from the vocab words 考える and 方. You might be more used to the on'yomi for 方 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember the kun'yomi (かた).

Your <vocabulary>way of thinking</vocabulary> is like a <reading>cata</reading>pult (かた). You just launch ideas at the wall and see what sticks. Sure it's a bit inexact, but it's the best <vocabulary>thought process</vocabulary> for you. The catapult way of thinking just suits you!

examples.en: The shape of today's rice ball is round.
examples.ja: 今日のおにぎりの形は丸です。

examples.en: The shape of Mt. Fuji is the same on both sides and is very beautiful.
examples.ja: ふじ山の形は、左右同じで、とてもきれいです。

examples.en: This flower is shaped like a fish.
examples.ja: この花、魚みたいな形をしていますね。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

What <vocabulary>shape</vocabulary> do you <reading>cut a chee</reading>se (かたち) into? Stars, triangles, little cubes, hearts! Anything but the boring slices other people do. You're like a mozzarella Michelangelo, the way you cut a cheese into those beautifully sculpted <vocabulary>form</vocabulary>s.

examples.en: There is a mountain in the south.
examples.ja: 南に山がある。

examples.en: The entrance is in the south.
examples.ja: 入り口は南の方にあります。

examples.en: I want to go to a southern country.
examples.ja: 南の国に行きたいなぁ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with the kanji, so you might remember it, but here's a mnemonic refresher just in case:

Think about the <vocabulary>south</vocabulary>. What's down there? <reading>Mean Amy</reading> (みなみ) lives down there. Think of the last mean thing she did to you and imagine it while yelling out "MEAN AMYYYYY" at the sky.

examples.en: This TV also has only one flaw.
examples.ja: このテレビにも、欠点は一つだけあります。

examples.en: Are there any drawbacks about going to Japan this year?
examples.ja: 今年、日本へ行くことについて、欠点は有りますか？

examples.en: Are there any defects for a perfect person like you?
examples.ja: あなたみたいなパーフェクトな人に、欠点なんてあるんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: You have a <kanji>lack</kanji> of <kanji>point</kanji>s. These are things about yourself you wish were better. These are your <vocabulary>shortcoming</vocabulary>s.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out because けつ is being shortened to けっ here!

examples.en: Mister Bill Gates was born in Seattle.
examples.ja: ビル・ゲイツ氏はシアトルの生まれです。

examples.en: Mr. Tanaka never came.
examples.ja: 田中氏は、いつまでも来ませんでした。

examples.en: This is a letter from Ms. Swift.
examples.ja: これがスウィフト氏からの手紙です。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>family name</kanji> because it goes after a family name in very formal situations. So, it's really closely tied to that. Because only men got the respect back in the day, we're calling this vocab word <vocabulary>mister</vocabulary>. You can call me Mr. Koichi if you'd like, too.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the kanji.

examples.en: Please enter your full name.
examples.ja: 氏名を入力して下さい。

examples.en: This is my husband's first and last name.
examples.ja: これは、主人の氏名です。

examples.en: This list also has your name.
examples.ja: このリストには、あなたの氏名も入ってます。

meaning_mnemonic: Both of these kanji have to do with names. You have both <kanji>family name</kanji> and <kanji>name</kanji>. Both of those names together makes for a <vocabulary>First And Last Name</vocabulary>... a <vocabulary>full name</vocabulary> if you will.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I have the freedom to take a day off today.
examples.ja: 私には今日休む自由がある。

examples.en: The child became independent, and both the mother and the father gained their freedom.
examples.ja: 子どもが自立し、母も父も自由を手に入れた。

examples.en: It is your freedom to go to the Philippines or not.
examples.ja: フィリピンに行くかどうかは、あなたの自由ですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: When you have <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>reason</kanji>, you are able to think for yourself. When you can think for yourself, you have <vocabulary>freedom</vocabulary>. Very philosophical, this vocab is.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There is no reason.
examples.ja: 理由は有りません。

examples.en: I don't know the reason for the leave of absence.
examples.ja: 休学の理由は分かりません。

examples.en: I don't know why, but my husband says he has to go abroad right now.
examples.ja: 理由は分かりませんが、主人が今すぐ海外に行かなければいけないと言ってるんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>reason</kanji> <kanji>reason</kanji> is a <vocabulary>reason</vocabulary>! How could it not be? Do you have a reason why it shouldn't be? I thought not.

This word means "reason" as in the reason you're studying Japanese, or the reason you're late. That's why it can also mean similar words like <vocabulary>motive</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>excuse</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Can I get the change all in 1,000 yen bills?
examples.ja: おつりは、全て千円札でもらえますか？

examples.en: Is it okay to use a hundred dollar bill?
examples.ja: 百ドル札でもいいですか？

examples.en: I only have 10,000 yen bills.
examples.ja: 一万円札しかないんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. When you see this word after a number, it’s for physical <vocabulary>bill</vocabulary>s of money.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a suffix that takes the on’yomi reading, which you’ve learned already!

You'll also see this pronounced ふだ, but that's when it's a standalone word or part of a compound, rather than a suffix. So if you answer with that reading, you'll be prompted to enter the suffix reading instead.

examples.en: We don't have enough thousand yen bills for change.
examples.ja: 千円札のおつりが不足しています。

examples.en: I bought three lottery tickets with a thousand yen bill.
examples.ja: 千円札で宝くじを三口買いました。

examples.en: This crane game doesn't accept thousand yen bills.
examples.ja: このUFOキャッチャーは千円札が使えません。

meaning_mnemonic: You know what 千円 is (1000 yen). So if you add a <kanji>bill</kanji> to that you get a <vocabulary>thousand yen bill</vocabulary>. That's just the little rectangular piece of money that is worth 1000 yen.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I am a Japanese citizen.
examples.ja: 私は、日本の国民です。

examples.en: It was the people's idea to make all 365 days holidays.
examples.ja: ３６５日全てを休みにするというのは、国民のアイディアでした。

examples.en: August 10th is Mountain Day. Mountain Day is a holiday for Japanese nationals.
examples.ja: 八月十日は山の日です。山の日は、日本の国民の休日です。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>country</kanji> <kanji>peoples</kanji> are the people of your country. They are <vocabulary>the people</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There are not many people in this area.
examples.ja: この辺は、人が少ないです。

examples.en: Is there a restaurant you would recommended in this area?
examples.ja: この辺に、おすすめのレストランはありますか？

examples.en: Is your company around here?
examples.ja: あなたの会社は、この辺ですか？

meaning_mnemonic: この means "this" so この辺 just means <vocabulary>this area</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for the kanji portion is just what you've already learned with the kanji 辺 so this shouldn't be a difficult one to read for you.

examples.en: Do you want to put ketchup on your hotdog?
examples.ja: ホットドッグにケチャップ付ける？

examples.en: My mother had a gold bracelet on her wrist.
examples.ja: お母さんは手首に金のブレスレットを付けていました。

examples.en: Koichi named the dog "Nikka."
examples.ja: コウイチは、犬に「ニッカ」という名を付けました。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>attach</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to attach something</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is actually the same as the one you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this one just fine.

examples.en: Please give me some alcohol other than beer.
examples.ja: ビール以外のアルコール下さい。

examples.en: There are no Japanese books except manga.
examples.ja: マンガ以外は日本の本が有りません。

examples.en: Is there anything else I can do other than going there right now?
examples.ja: 今すぐ行く以外に、私に何か出来ることがありますか？

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Compared with</kanji> this, it's <kanji>outside</kanji> what you wanted. You'll have anything <vocabulary>other than</vocabulary> that.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm fine with a hotel that costs ten thousand yen or more.
examples.ja: 一万円以上のホテルでもいいですよ。

examples.en: What!? There are shampoos that go for 10,000 yen or more!?
examples.ja: え、一万円以上するシャンプーなんてあるの！？

examples.en: By car, it takes ten or more hours to get to Quebec.
examples.ja: 車だと、ケベックまで10時間以上かかりますよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Start <kanji>from</kanji> something and then go <kanji>above</kanji> it. Now you have "<vocabulary>no less than</vocabulary> ___," or, in other words, "___ <vocabulary>or more</vocabulary>"! 

When used with numbers, 以上 always includes the number itself, like 十人以上 (10 or more people). In non-numerical contexts, it can mean "more than" in a looser sense, like これ以上もてない (I can't carry more than this).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That man is someone I've met before.
examples.ja: あの男の人は、以前会ったことがある人です。

examples.en: Before, I used to come to Sydney often.
examples.ja: 以前は、シドニーによく来ていました。

examples.en: Active fund performance before the year 2000 was much better than it is now.
examples.ja: ２０００年以前のアクティブファンドのパフォーマンスは、今よりずっといいんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>From</kanji> <kanji>before</kanji>, just means <vocabulary>previously</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>before</vocabulary> now.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: If you jump that much, you would lose your physical strength.
examples.ja: そんなにジャンプすると体力を失うよ。

examples.en: This year, I lost a lot of money from gambling.
examples.ja: 今年は、ギャンブルでたくさんのお金を失った。

examples.en: From the day I lost my father, I started looking at the sky a lot.
examples.ja: 父を失った日から、よく空を見るようになりました。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji portion means <kanji>fault</kanji>, so you would think the verb version is "to fault." It's a little different, though. Think of it this way, if you "fault" something, you're messing up. What's a great way to mess up? By losing something. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to lose</vocabulary>. 

Pretend like you are supposed to hold on to someone's wedding ring. You make the biggest fault of all. You lose it. Ouch.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

So how did you lose the wedding ring anyway? Well... it was eaten by a cow. The <reading>牛 now</reading> (うし + なう) has to have it surgically removed. What a mess!

examples.en: Such a rude man.
examples.ja: なんて失礼な男だ。

examples.en: Excuse me if this is impolite, but how old are you?
examples.ja: 失礼ですが、年はいくつですか？

examples.en: I'll excuse myself before you then.
examples.ja: では、お先に失礼します。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you do something that's your <kanji>fault</kanji> and then you say "<kanji>thanks</kanji>" after you do it, that's super-duper <vocabulary>rude</vocabulary>, wouldn't you say? Imagine doing something like this and then thinking to yourself after... wow, I was really rude.

This is also often used to mean <vocabulary>excuse me</vocabulary>, typically followed by ですが or します. Occasionally, it’s also used just on its own, usually when the speaker holds a higher or equal status to the person being spoken to. This particular usage is more prevalent among older generations and is commonly associated with masculine speech.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It is important to make sure to walk every day.
examples.ja: 必ず毎日歩くことが大切です。

examples.en: Please be sure to come to the next class.
examples.ja: 次のクラスは、必ず来てください。

examples.en: I'll surely complete WaniKani before I die.
examples.ja: 死ぬ前に、必ずワニカニをコンプリートします。

meaning_mnemonic: This word looks like a verb but it's not (sorry!). It's an adverb. The kanji itself means <kanji>certain</kanji> and the vocab version means all sorts of variations on that: <vocabulary>surely</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>certainly</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>without exception</vocabulary> to name a few.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Ra, the Egyptian god asks you: "Can you do it? Are you <vocabulary>certain</vocabulary> you can build the pyramids?" 

"Yes I <reading>can ra</reading> (かなら). Yes I can," you reply.

examples.en: Mom is frantic about losing weight.
examples.ja: お母さんは、ダイエットに必死だ。

examples.en: I ran desperately, but the bus had already left.
examples.ja: 必死に走ったが、バスはもう出てしまった。

examples.en: It was a desperate proposal, but it wasn't successful.
examples.ja: 必死のプロポーズだったが、ダメだった。

meaning_mnemonic:
Your future consists of <kanji>certain</kanji> <kanji>death</kanji>. How would you feel in this situation? Probably very <vocabulary>frantic</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>desperate</vocabulary>. 

Another translation for this word is simply <vocabulary>certain death</vocabulary>, though I'd rather you learn one of the first two before this one if you can.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the on'yomi readings, though 必 (ひつ) gets shortened to ひっ. In your <vocabulary>desperate</vocabulary> situation just imagine that you're trying to get out of it, and to do so you move the つ only to find a smaller っ blocking your way. It is certain death.

examples.en: I don't know the future.
examples.ja: 未来のことは分かりません。

examples.en: If I could time travel, I’d want to go to the future.
examples.ja: タイムスリップできるなら、未来に行きたいな。

examples.en: I hope the future of Japanese children today is bright.
examples.ja: 今の日本の子の未来は明るいといいな。

meaning_mnemonic:
What has <kanji>not yet</kanji> <kanji>come</kanji>? The <vocabulary>future</vocabulary>.

未来 is usually used to talk about the distant future, and it implies that the future can’t be foreseen. So you can use it to speculate about what might lie ahead, but you probably wouldn’t use it to discuss more concrete plans, goals or predictions.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: After a leave of absence, I became a company president in Kyushu.
examples.ja: 休学の末、私は九州で社長になりました。

examples.en: It's the end of the world to me, as a writer, that AI can make a sentence like this.
examples.ja: AIがこんな文も作れるなんて、ライターの私にとっては、世も末ですよ。

examples.en: My youngest sister is still five years old.
examples.ja: 末の妹は、まだ五才です。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Throw a "the" in there if you'd like, as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

You've reached <vocabulary>the end</vocabulary> of the universe. Nothing is there. You step out, and you're surprised because you get greeted by an old Canadian man. <reading>Sue, eh?</reading>(すえ) he asks you, over and over. The poor man is looking for his wife Sue, and he's searched to the end of the universe. That's true love. As he walks off into the distance, you hear him calling out, "Sue, eh? Sue, eh? Sue, eh?"

examples.en: In Japan, we eat buckwheat noodles at the end of the year.
examples.ja: 日本では年末にソバを食べます。

examples.en: At the end of the year, the town is full of life.
examples.ja: 年末は、町の中に活気があふれます。

examples.en: At the end of the year, there is a culture of cleaning for the entire year.
examples.ja: 年末は、一年分のクリーニングをする文化があります。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>year</kanji> <kanji>end</kanji> is the <vocabulary>year end</vocabulary> aka the <vocabulary>end of the year</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: By the end of the month, I will leave this apartment.
examples.ja: 月末までに、このアパートを出ます。

examples.en: The party is at the end of the month.
examples.ja: パーティーは月末です。

examples.en: The money from the part-time job comes in at the end of the month.
examples.ja: バイトのお金は月末に入ります。

meaning_mnemonic: You know how 月 can also mean <kanji>month</kanji>? If you add 末 on there you have the "month end" aka the <vocabulary>end of the month</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 月 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

examples.en: It only takes 10 minutes to get to the high school if you drive.

examples.en: My younger sister is a junior in high school this year. Next year, there will be a university entrance test.

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>tall</kanji> <kanji>school</kanji> is for when your kids get about as tall as they're going to get. That's <vocabulary>high school</vocabulary>, when most people stop growing taller.

examples.en: I go to school on weekdays.

examples.en: Rachel is a friend from my school.

examples.en: In my school, there are four class groups for third graders.

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>study</kanji> <kanji>school</kanji> is obviously a place where people study and learn. In English, that's simply a <vocabulary>school</vocabulary>.

examples.en: What reminds me of summer is draft beer and fireworks.

examples.en: In summer, I sometimes eat two bowls of shaved ice a day.

examples.en: The 1900 Summer Olympics were held in Paris.

reading_mnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the reading for the vocab.

examples.en: July and August are summer vacation.
examples.ja: 七月と八月は夏休みです。

examples.en: I played games a lot during summer vacation.
examples.ja: 夏休み中に、たくさんゲームをしました。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 夏 means <kanji>summer</kanji> and 休 means <kanji>rest</kanji>. What is a "summer rest" though? It's a <vocabulary>summer break</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>summer vacation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are kun'yomi readings because this word is essentially two separate words put together into one word. You should know the reading for 夏 from the kanji and the reading for 休み from the vocab.

examples.en: Put the paper and pen on the table.
examples.ja: 紙とペンをテーブルの上に出してください。

examples.en: The Japanese 10,000 yen bill is money made out of paper.
examples.ja: 日本の一万円札は紙のお金です。

examples.en: This is how to make a doll using paper and thread.
examples.ja: これが、紙と糸を用いた人形の作り方です。

reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but lucky for you that's the reading you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this vocab too.

examples.en: It is a letter from my father.
examples.ja: それは、父からの手紙です。

examples.en: Perhaps, it didn't have enough stamps. A letter from the school still hasn't arrived.
examples.ja: 切手が足りなかったのか、学校からの手紙が中々来ません。

examples.en: Can you teach me how to mail out a letter to a foreign country?
examples.ja: 外国への手紙の出し方を教えてくれませんか？

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>hand</kanji> <kanji>paper</kanji> is a <vocabulary>letter</vocabulary> because letters are generally written by hand on paper.

If you want a more graphic image, imagine writing a letter on your hand, and how much it would hurt to chop off your hand and send it.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is double kun'yomi. Think of 手紙 as two words mashed together — a letter is a thing you write by hand (て) on paper (かみ). You've learned those readings already, so you should be able to read this! Just watch out for the rendaku on がみ.

examples.en: Please do not look at the diary on the table.

examples.en: It takes about 30 minutes to write a journal every day.

examples.en: The cover of this diary was 10,000 yen.
examples.ja: この日記のカバーは一万円でした。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>write down</kanji> your <kanji>day</kanji> (and do it every day) that's your <vocabulary>diary</vocabulary>.

When you write down your day in your <vocabulary>diary</vocabulary>, in fact you write only about <reading>Nicky</reading> (にっき). You love Nicky so much, your diary is full of Nicky this, Nicky that. Ah, Nicky is just the best.

examples.en: Please be careful with car traffic.

meaning_mnemonic: Even though it gets <kanji>mix</kanji>ed up as it <kanji>passes through</kanji> itself, modern <vocabulary>traffic</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>transport</vocabulary> systems are pretty amazing. This word refers to traffic and transport for pedestrians, bikes, cars, buses, trains, planes... anything that gets us from A to B.

examples.en: A million yen for a business suit is too expensive.

meaning_mnemonic:
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>tall</kanji> or <kanji>expensive</kanji>? It's the same: <vocabulary>tall</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>expensive</vocabulary>. 

Weird that this word means both of these things, yeah? Just imagine money piled up to be really tall. That money is tall because it needs to buy something expensive.

examples.ja: 全日本の女子バレーチームは、中々強い

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you wanna be <vocabulary>strong</vocabulary>, you need to be able to use <reading>two yo</reading>-yos (つよ) at a time. Like, as weapons. And I don't mean with two hands. I mean one hand wielding two yo-yos. Now that's strong.

examples.en: This hair dryer is quite powerful.

meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>strong</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji>. You are <vocabulary>strong</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>powerful</vocabulary>. Feel your <vocabulary>strength</vocabulary>.

It's a legendary lock produced in ancient きょうと, rumored to be the strongest lock in existence. What magical powers do you think lie behind the <vocabulary>strength</vocabulary> of the きょうと lock?

examples.en: I always teach my child the importance of saying "thank you."

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>teach</kanji> so the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to teach</vocabulary>. It's also used to mean <vocabulary>to tell</vocabulary> in a more general sense.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Think about your favorite teacher. Now think about them teaching you the following: "Today I'm going to teach you about the <reading>ocea</reading>n (おし)." It is big. Really big. Inside it are krakens, space aliens, and lost cities. 

Here is where you continue the lesson in your head, making it the most ridiculous lesson about the ocean you've ever heard. Focus in on the ocean part, since that's the reading, always coming back to it.

examples.en: This is a classroom for first-graders.

Though it may seem kind of strange that geography is bringing reason to the earth, if you think of geography as a study, then you can think about how you try to get reason through that, as well.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. That's the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this one too. If you need a refresher, here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're part of a special <vocabulary>group</vocabulary>. It is the <reading>cumi</reading>n group, and they deal with all things cumin (the spice or seed). Smell the cumin. Touch it. Taste it. You live and breathe the stuff, because you are the president of this cumin group.

P.S. This can also be spelled 組み (same reading: くみ) when it's a counter for groups, like ひと組み or ふた組み.

examples.en: This is a boat going to Shikoku.

examples.ja: 船の上から見る日の出はきれいです。

reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

You're riding in a boat. It's great. Imagine it being the best time you've had in your life. You tell everyone: "This is <reading>fun, eh</reading>?" (ふね). You're on a Canadian ship, which is why you add the "eh" in there. Say this out loud wherever you are right now while imagining the sea smell, the wind, and the excitement of boats.

examples.en: You can see many balloons in the sky.

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>wind</kanji> <kanji>boat</kanji>. This is a strange one for sure. You may assume this is like one of those giant balloons you can go ride around in, and you'd be partly right. Really, this word covers the general word <vocabulary>balloon</vocabulary>, though it especially has to do with the toy-style balloons (or smaller balloons). It's a little round wind ship!
