meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

Imagine a <vocabulary>fish</vocabulary>. Now imagine the fish playing soccer, while wearing a nun's outfit. This is a <reading>soccer nu</reading>n (さかな).

examples.en: Is this a goldfish? Is it carp?
examples.ja: これは、金魚ですか？コイですか？

examples.en: Please give me a goldfish with red and white dots.
examples.ja: 赤と白の点が入ってる金魚を下さい。

examples.en: Are there any goldfish in the river?
examples.ja: 川に、金魚はいますか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>gold</kanji> <kanji>fish</kanji> is really just gold in color, but it's still called a <vocabulary>goldfish</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That bird is an American eagle.
examples.ja: あの鳥は、アメリカンイーグルです。

examples.en: The birds in the sky look like dots.
examples.ja: 空にいる鳥が点のように見えます。

examples.en: Dad, there's bird poop on the car.
examples.ja: お父さん、車に鳥のフンがついてるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

When you think about birds, what is the most common bird you can think of? What bird do you hate the most or like eating the most? Either one will work. Now, imagine yourself going up to that bird. You did something terrible. You <reading>tore</reading> (とり) off its wing and started eating it (pretend it's cooked first, if that makes you less nauseous).

examples.en: Swan wings are white and beautiful.
examples.ja: 白鳥の羽は、白くてきれいです。

examples.en: Every year, a lot of swans come to the river nearby.
examples.ja: 毎年、近くの川に白鳥がたくさん来ます。

examples.en: In addition to the swan, there are ducks too.
examples.ja: 白鳥の他にも、アヒルがいますね。

meaning_mnemonic: There are many <kanji>white</kanji> <kanji>bird</kanji>s out there, for sure, but one really stands out if you ask me. That bird is the <vocabulary>swan</vocabulary>. It's big, it's white, and it's majestic.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My raincoat is yellow.
examples.ja: 私のレインコートは黄色です。

examples.en: There are many yellow flowers growing on the grassland.
examples.ja: その草地には黄色の花がたくさん生えています。

examples.en: My mother is wearing a yellow shirt.
examples.ja: お母さんが黄色いシャツを着ています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>yellow</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> is just the color <vocabulary>yellow</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the same as the readings you learned with the kanji meaning you should be able to read this word right off the bat.

examples.en: A black pen, please.
examples.ja: 黒いペン、下さい。

examples.en: I'm thinking of going to the prom in a black dress.
examples.ja: プロムには黒いドレスで行こうと思う。

examples.en: Since our pet dog's fur is black, we do not have any white wool sweaters.
examples.ja: ペットの犬の毛が黒いので、うちには白い羊毛のセーターが有りません。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>black</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>black</vocabulary>. Special Note: The noun version of black also exists in Japanese. It is just 黒 with the same pronunciation, but minus the い which makes it adjective-tastic.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Think of black things. One very common black thing is the common <reading>crow</reading> (くろ). Associate those two together.

examples.en: Toronto has a big community of Black people.
examples.ja: トロントには、大きな黒人のコミュニティがあります。

examples.en: There are still not many shampoos and foundations for Black people in Japan.
examples.ja: 日本には、まだまだ黒人用のシャンプーやファンデーションが少ない。

examples.en: My mother is Black and my father is Asian.
examples.ja: 母は黒人で、父はアジア人です。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>black</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is simply a <vocabulary>Black person</vocabulary>, kind of like how a 白人 is a "White person," but a different  color.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Imagine a <vocabulary>Black person</vocabulary> you know well wearing <reading>coke</reading> <reading>jean</reading>s (こくじん). Yep, jeans made entirely from coke bottles. That's actually a thing. Look it up if you don't believe me.

examples.en: This is my younger sister's doll.
examples.ja: これは私の妹の人形です。

examples.en: When I was little, I collected used dolls.
examples.ja: 小さい時、中古の人形をコレクションしていました。

examples.en: The girl cherishes all her dolls — ​​Barbie doll, Mel-chan doll, and Rika-chan doll — as if they're her own children.
examples.ja: その女の子は、バービー人形、メルちゃん人形、リカちゃん人形、全ての人形を自分の子のように大切にしています。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>person</kanji> <kanji>shape</kanji>d that isn't a person? That has to be some kind of <vocabulary>doll</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>puppet</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, and the reading of 形 is a bit of an oddball, here's a mnemonic to help you:

Did you know that all <vocabulary>doll</vocabulary>s at <reading>Nin</reading>tendo are made out of <reading>gyo</reading>za dumplings (にんぎょう)? They'll also regularly try to get you to eat them... Mmmm, gyoza dolls. Don't be afraid to take a bite!

examples.en: This table was handmade by Hayashi.
examples.ja: このテーブルは、林さんの手作りです。

examples.en: A friend gave me a handmade gift.
examples.ja: 友人が手作りのプレゼントをくれました。

examples.en: Handmade pasta is popular in this restaurant.
examples.ja: このレストランでは手作りのパスタが人気です。

meaning_mnemonic: When something is <kanji>hand</kanji> <kanji>made</kanji>, it is <vocabulary>handmade</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: The readings for these kanji are the kun'yomi readings. Just think of this word as two separate words put together (手 and 作る). The る in 作る gets changed to り because it's an adjective, and the つ in つくり gets changed to づ because of the way the words are combined with each other. You should know most of the reading that is in this word, though it will probably take a little bit of thinking to sort out the little changes in those readings.

examples.en: There is a little bit of wind today.
examples.ja: 今日は、少し風がありますね。

examples.en: Wind is blowing towards south.
examples.ja: 南向きの風がふいています。

examples.en: The wind is strong today because the typhoon is coming nearby.
examples.ja: 今日は、台風が近くに来ているせいで、風が強いです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Do you know the word "kamikaze" from WWII history? Well, it means "divine wind." The "kaze" part is the wind part, and this word uses the same reading, making it <reading>かぜ</reading> as well.

examples.en: As soon as you get out of the south exit, there is a tea shop.
examples.ja: 南口から出るとすぐにお茶の店があります。

examples.en: It seems that there will be a convenience store at the south exit next summer.
examples.ja: 来年の夏には南口にコンビニができるらしい。

examples.en: The bench at the south exit is a popular dating spot for grandmas and grandpas.
examples.ja: 南口のベンチは、おばあちゃんとおじいちゃんに人気のデートスポットです。

meaning_mnemonic: After learning 北口, 西口, and 東口, it's time for round four! Yep, you guessed it, adding <kanji>south</kanji> to 口 makes this <vocabulary>south exit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>south entrance</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Just like 北口 and the others, this also uses kun'yomi readings. And just like before, watch out for the rendaku that changes くち to ぐち!

examples.en: Most of the staff here are college students.
examples.ja: ここのスタッフは大体、大学生です。

examples.en: Many college students take a leave of absence from school.
examples.ja: 大学生は休学する人が多いです。

examples.en: Do you know the life of an American college student?
examples.ja: アメリカの大学生の生活を知ってますか？

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 学生 means "student" and you know that 大学 means university/college. Combine the two and you have a <vocabulary>university student</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>college student</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The teacher corrected my way of saying "Excuse me."
examples.ja: 先生が「すみません」の言い方を正してくれました。

examples.en: I think that way of speaking is rude.
examples.ja: その言い方は失礼だと思います。

examples.en: You will know where they're from by how they say "Thank you."
examples.ja: 「ありがとう」の言い方で、その人の生まれが分かります。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>say</kanji>ing <kanji>way</kanji> is… your <vocabulary>way of saying</vocabulary>! This refers to the words you use and how you phrase things, as well as how you say it.
reading_mnemonic:
This uses the kun'yomi readings from the vocab words 言う and 方. You might be more used to the on'yomi for 方 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember the kun'yomi (かた).

Your <vocabulary>way of saying</vocabulary> things is to <reading>cata</reading>pult (かた) them right into people's ears. Just catapult those words like you're trying to break through their ear drums.

examples.en: The police went ahead and headed to the white car.
examples.ja: パトカーは先回りして白い車に向かった。

examples.en: I went ahead and made dinner.
examples.ja: 先回りして、夜ごはんは作っておいたよ。

examples.en: The company president is a person who can do various things ahead.
examples.ja: 社長は、先回りして色々なことを行える人です。

meaning_mnemonic: If you get there <kanji>previous</kanji> to something rotating (回り), you are <vocabulary>arriving ahead</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>going ahead</vocabulary> in <vocabulary>anticipation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This consists of a couple kun'yomi readings put together. You can tell it's kun'yomi because of the hiragana sticking out at the end. In previous levels, you learned both the words 先 and 回る (verb version of 回り). If you know those, you should be able to put them together to learn the reading of this word as well.

examples.en: Let's meet up soon.
examples.ja: 近々、会いましょう。

examples.en: A baby will be born soon.
examples.ja: 近々、赤ちゃんが生まれます。

examples.en: I will go to China soon.
examples.ja: 近々、中国に行きますよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
When something is <kanji>close</kanji> <kanji>close</kanji> (the 々 character repeats the kanji that was before it) it will happen <vocabulary>in the near future</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>soon</vocabulary>. 

This is pretty vague, and it's up to the person speaking to decide how soon <vocabulary>soon</vocabulary> is. Depending on the person and the situation, it could technically be used for anything up to a few years!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading twice; that's the one you learn with the vocab word 近い from the previous level. The second 近 gets converted to ぢか, though, so take note of that. To write the character ぢ, type "di" on your keyboard.

examples.en: The blue sky is spreading out today.
examples.ja: 今日は青空が広がっている。

examples.en: We did a cherry blossom viewing under the blue sky.
examples.ja: 青空の下で花見をしました。

examples.en: Many days in May have a blue sky.
examples.ja: 五月は青空の日が多いですね。

meaning_mnemonic: This is simply a <kanji>blue</kanji> <kanji>sky</kanji> (aka a <vocabulary>blue sky</vocabulary>!).
reading_mnemonic:
You'd think that this word would use on'yomi readings to read it, but it doesn't (shake that angry fist at the kanji gods!). Instead, it's double kun'yomi, probably because this word is really like two separate words put together, "blue" and "sky." In the previous level you unlocked these two separate words, learning their readings. That means you should be able to read this as well. 

One quick note is the rendaku-fication of 空 as well. It becomes ぞら.

examples.en: Both brothers are still elementary school students.
examples.ja: その兄弟は、まだ二人とも小学生です。

examples.en: I've been playing basketball since I was an elementary schooler.
examples.ja: 小学生の時から、ずっとバスケットボールをしています。

examples.en: When I was in elementary school, the stone and the marbles were like my friends.
examples.ja: 小学生の時、石ころとビー玉は、友人みたいなものでした。

meaning_mnemonic: You know 学生 is student, so what is a <kanji>small</kanji> student? Think young. That would be an <vocabulary>Elementary School Student</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Is this the right way to make macaroni cheese?
examples.ja: このマカロニチーズの作り方は正しいですか？

examples.en: Please teach me how to make curry.
examples.ja: カレーの作り方を教えて下さい。

examples.en: When you don't know how to make it, check it on the Internet.
examples.ja: 作り方が分からない時は、インターネットでチェックしましょう。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the <kanji>way</kanji> to <kanji>make</kanji> something. This is <vocabulary>how to make</vocabulary> something. You'll see this for directions on building something.
reading_mnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi readings from the vocab words 作る and 方. So as long as you're okay with those, you can apply that knowledge over here.

examples.en: My child is a junior high school student now.
examples.ja: 私の子は、今中学生です。

examples.en: This is an essay I wrote when I was in junior high.
examples.ja: これは中学生のときの作文です。

examples.en: I participated in a piano competition for junior high school students.
examples.ja: 中学生向けのピアノのコンクールに出ました。

examples.en: Oyama-sensei is my teacher from when I was a junior high school student.
examples.ja: 大山先生は、中学生の時の先生です。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen 学生 (means student). Now let's look at a student who's in the middle. Perhaps we can call this a <vocabulary>middle school student</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>junior high school student</vocabulary>, depending on where you're from.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Are there any anime that were unpopular this year?
examples.ja: 今年、不人気だったアニメは有りますか？

examples.en: It's an unpopular band in Japan, but I think that song is a masterpiece.
examples.ja: 日本では不人気なバンドですが、私は、あの曲は名曲だと思います。

examples.en: This YouTuber is famous for being unpopular with women.
examples.ja: このYouTuberは、女の人から不人気なことで有名です。

meaning_mnemonic: You already know 人気 which means "popular." And you also know that 不 means "not." So what do you get when you combine the two? Something that's <vocabulary>not popular</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>unpopular</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What kind of movies do you usually watch?
examples.ja: いつもどんな映画を見ますか？

examples.en: Would you like to go see a movie together?
examples.ja: いっしょに映画を見に行きませんか？

examples.en: This is a horror movie.
examples.ja: これはホラー映画です。

meaning_mnemonic: It's a <kanji>reflect</kanji>ion of an <kanji>image</kanji> on a screen, and the image is moving! What is this? It's a <vocabulary>movie</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I never understand my mother's mentality.
examples.ja: 母の心理が、どうしても分からない。

examples.en: My sister went to college to become a psychological counselor.
examples.ja: 姉は心理カウンセラーになるために大学へ行きました。

examples.en: In most cases, you can tell the person's mental state from their gesture.
examples.ja: 大体のケースは人の仕草から、その人の心理を知ることが出来るんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>reason</kanji>ing of your <kanji>heart</kanji> decides what you do. Probably when kanji was being made people thought that the heart directed our actions, not our brains. So, if you think about it that way, the reasoning of your heart is your <vocabulary>mental state</vocabulary>. Nowadays that's known as <vocabulary>psychology</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This is how we cut out the heart shape.
examples.ja: こうやってハートの形を切り取るんです。

examples.en: Can you clip this coupon for me?
examples.ja: このクーポンを切り取っておいてもらえますか？

examples.en: I am sure the media will only cut out the parts that are newsworthy.
examples.ja: マスコミはきっとニュースになりそうなところだけを切り取るだろ。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>cut</kanji> and <kanji>take</kanji> something, you are going to cut it right off. So, this verb is <vocabulary>to cut off</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from 切る and 取る. So, know those words separately and you can combine them into this word.

examples.en: I saw a man take the smartphone out of Michael’s bag.
examples.ja: 男が、マイケルのカバンからスマホを取り出すのを見たよ。

examples.en: The woman took a pen out of her pocket.
examples.ja: 女はポケットからペンを取り出した。

examples.en: Can you take the pufferfish out of the oven for me?
examples.ja: オーブンからフグを取り出しておいてくれない？

meaning_mnemonic: To <kanji>take</kanji> something and then <kanji>remove</kanji> it, is when you reach in and grab something and choose it and pull it out. This is <vocabulary>to pick out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to take out</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the individual words 取る and 出す. Put them together and you should be able to read this word too.

examples.en: Why do elephants have long trunks?
examples.ja: どうして象のハナは長いの？

examples.en: Look, there's an elephant over there.
examples.ja: 見て、あそこに象さんがいる。

examples.en: My legs are swollen, and look like elephant legs.
examples.ja: 足がむくんで、象の足みたいになっています。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the ぞう reading of the kanji. You're at the ぞう show. How exciting.

examples.en: Even in this era, there are fax machines in Japan.
examples.ja: 今の時代でも、日本にはファックスが有ります。

examples.en: This is a book of a love story from the Heian period.
examples.ja: これは、平安時代のラブストーリーの本です。

examples.en: In the current time period, the Internet will tell you everything.
examples.ja: 今の時代、インターネットが全てを教えてくれます。

meaning_mnemonic: You have a <kanji>period</kanji> of <kanji>time</kanji> and it's called a <vocabulary>period</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>era</vocabulary>! Simple!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Is this stone really important?
examples.ja: この石ころ、本当に大切？

examples.en: I'm worried if this map is truly accurate.
examples.ja: この地図が本当に正しいか不安です。

examples.en: Is this car seriously used?
examples.ja: この車、本当に中古なんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: 本当 is <kanji>reality</kanji> or <kanji>truth</kanji> (level 5 vocab). If you add on に, this changes the word to an adverb, and we get <vocabulary>really</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>truly</vocabulary>. 本当に!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It shares the reading with the level 5 本当 as well, but just has a particle on the end. Really!

examples.en: Social rules are important.
examples.ja: 社会のルールは大切だ。

examples.en: I am worried about the Japanese social system.
examples.ja: 日本社会のシステムに不安があります。

examples.en: Foreigners are members of the society too.
examples.ja: 外国人も社会のメンバーです。

meaning_mnemonic: Not to be confused with 会社, which is a company, this is <vocabulary>society</vocabulary>. When a <kanji>company</kanji> <kanji>meet</kanji>s together, it's like a bunch of people, who are in groups, who come together to live in one world. That is a <vocabulary>society</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Tomorrow is Valentine's Day.
examples.ja: 明日はバレンタインデーです。

examples.en: I'll take a day off from work tomorrow.
examples.ja: 明日は会社を休みます。

examples.en: Can I give my answer regarding the house loan tomorrow?
examples.ja: 家のローンに対しての答えを出すのは明日でもいいですか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>bright</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> isn't today (because today was terrible), it's <vocabulary>tomorrow</vocabulary>, because you can always look to tomorrow to be a better, brighter day.
reading_mnemonic:
The あした reading is irregular, though you can just think of the あ part as coming from the 明 kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember the whole reading as well:

It'll be a better, brighter day <vocabulary>tomorrow</vocabulary> because you're making <reading>ash ta</reading>cos (あした). Mmm, imagine the taste of those delicious ash tacos you'll be having tomorrow.

Note: あした is the usual, everyday way to say "tomorrow," while あす is a more formal version you'll hear in news reports and weather forecasts, for example.

examples.en: The convenience store in 1-chome has just opened.
examples.ja: 一丁目のコンビニはオープンしたばかりです。

examples.en: Tanaka-san's apartment is in 3-chome.
examples.ja: 田中さんのアパートは、三丁目です。

examples.en: You have no choice but to walk to the company as there's no bus coming to 4-chome.
examples.ja: 四丁目にはバスが来ないので、会社までは歩くしかありません。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>street</kanji> you can see with your <kanji>eye</kanji> isn't soooo big you can't see it (like a town would be), but it's still pretty big because it has a street. This section of the town is the <vocabulary>district of a town</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>city block</vocabulary> (though specifically one of an irregular size).
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, so use those and you'll be A-Okay.

examples.en: I will mop the floor today.
examples.ja: 今日は床にモップをかけます。

examples.en: There are cockroaches on the floor!
examples.ja: 床にゴキブリがいる！

examples.en: That is my brother doing yoga on the floor.
examples.ja: 床の上でヨガをしているのが私の兄です。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, but here’s a mnemonic in case you need a refresher:

You look at the floor. It's disgusting. Dirtiest and nastiest floor you've ever seen. You say <reading>yucka</reading> (ゆか) because it's covered in <reading>yucca</reading> (ゆか). Plus, it's all rotten. Yucka!

examples.en: See you here at 3:00 p.m. on the 3rd.
examples.ja: 三日の午後三時に、ここで会いましょう。

examples.en: What time is the meeting with the president?
examples.ja: 社長とのミーティングは何時ですか？

examples.en: I do WaniKani reviews in the bathroom at 3:00 p.m. every day.
examples.ja: 毎日午後三時にトイレの中でワニカニのレビューをします。

meaning_mnemonic: If there's a number before 時, it means <vocabulary>o'clock</vocabulary>. For example １時 is 1:00, and ２３時 is 23:00 or 11pm.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: If you see a taxi, please fully raise your right hand.
examples.ja: タクシーを見たら、右手を大きく上げて下さいね。

examples.en: Turn up the volume a little more, please.
examples.ja: ボリュームをもう少し大きくして下さい。

examples.en: This year, the dollar went up significantly.
examples.ja: 今年は、ドルが大きく上がった。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the adverb version of the kanji <kanji>big</kanji>. It's a little thing you can put in front of things to say that they are "<vocabulary>in a big way</vocabulary>" or "<vocabulary>on a grand scale</vocabulary>."
reading_mnemonic: Since you already know the reading of the vocab word 大きい, you should be able to read this word as well.

examples.en: Is there a convenience store nearby?
examples.ja: コンビニは近くにありますか？

examples.en: I got the TV at a used shop nearby.
examples.ja: テレビは近くの中古ショップで手に入れました。

examples.en: If you look closely, you would know it's not a real diamond.
examples.ja: 近くで見ると本当のダイアモンドじゃないって分かるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>near</kanji>. So it also means <vocabulary>near</vocabulary>, or in the <vocabulary>neighborhood</vocabulary> of something.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 近い, so you should be able to read this word as well.

examples.en: Soon, a typhoon will come to Kyushu.
examples.ja: もうすぐ九州に台風が来ます。

examples.en: Before the typhoon came, I put all the outside planters inside the house.
examples.ja: 台風が来る前に外のプランターを全て家の中に入れました。

examples.en: On a typhoon day, my dog ​​was under the bed all day.
examples.ja: 台風の日、うちの犬は一日中ベッドの下にいました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>machine</kanji> that pumps <kanji>wind</kanji> can malfunction and make too much, causing a <vocabulary>typhoon</vocabulary>. It's a really powerful machine to be able to move that much wind.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Instead of だい for 台 though, this uses the reading たい. Remember it like this:

When a <vocabulary>typhoon</vocabulary> is coming you have to <reading>tie</reading> (たい) down all of your stuff. Or, you know, if you already know the word typhoon, that's fine too.

examples.en: The hull was big.
examples.ja: 船体は大きかった。

examples.en: This hull is used.
examples.ja: この船体は中古です。

examples.en: It'll take at least a year for all the hulls to be built.
examples.ja: 全ての船体ができあがるまでには、少なくとも一年かかります。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>boat</kanji>'s <kanji>body</kanji> is called the <vocabulary>hull</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This is Room 302.
examples.ja: こちらが302号室です。

examples.en: Could you come to Room 103 at the Marina Hotel right now?
examples.ja: 今すぐマリーナホテルの103号室に来てもらえますか？

examples.en: The head office is located in Room 507 in that building.
examples.ja: 本社は、あのビルの507号室にあります。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a counter that can be used after numbers to let you know what <kanji>number</kanji> <kanji>room</kanji> it is. It's a <vocabulary>room number</vocabulary> that you use in apartments and hotels to know exactly which room you're looking for.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: On a day like this, let's just look up at the sky.
examples.ja: こんな日は、大空を見上げよう。

examples.en: Drones are spreading throughout the sky.
examples.ja: ドローンが大空に広がっている。

examples.en: I wonder if Grandpa is watching us from the heavens?
examples.ja: おじいちゃん、大空から私たちのこと見てくれているかな？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>big</kanji> thing in the <kanji>sky</kanji> is the <vocabulary>heavens</vocabulary>. The heavens where birds and planes soar, not the one you go to after you die if you've been really good.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that そら becomes ぞら because of rendaku here.

examples.en: On a rainy day, you see some people not coming to class.
examples.ja: 雨の日はクラスを休む人が見当たる。

examples.en: I went to a convenience store, but I couldn't find any ice cream.
examples.ja: コンビニに行っても、アイスが見当たらなかった。

examples.en: Even if I look closely at the map, I can't find the hotel.
examples.ja: 地図をよく見ても、中々ホテルが見当たらない。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. 

見当たる is made up of the kanji for  <kanji>see</kanji> and <kanji>right</kanji>, so what happens when you see the right thing? It was able <vocabulary>to be found</vocabulary>! 

This word is generally used in the negative form (見当たらない). You can use it as a roundabout expression for when you can’t find what you’re looking for.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This is how to make a triangular rice ball.
examples.ja: これが、三角形のおにぎりの作り方です。

examples.en: Triangular tiles in the kitchen are cute.
examples.ja: このキッチン、三角形のタイルが、かわいいですね。

examples.en: What can you tell from this triangular graph?
examples.ja: この三角形のグラフで、何が分かるんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: You already learned that 三角 means "triangle." Well this means <vocabulary>triangle</vocabulary> too, but it's the mathematical term. You should use it in math class.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I don't know the conjugation forms of "tatsu".
examples.ja: 「立つ」の活用形が分かりません。

examples.en: Please make a sentence using various conjugation forms.
examples.ja: 色々な活用形を用いて、文を作って下さい。

examples.en: I always double-check the conjugation forms in an app.
examples.ja: 活用形は、いつもアプリで見てダブルチェックします。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 活用 means "conjugation" and that 〜形 means "form," so that means this is the <vocabulary>conjugated form</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: What the heck is going on?
examples.ja: 一体どうなっているんだ。

examples.en: Where on earth can I get these sandals?
examples.ja: 一体どこに行けば、このサンダルが手に入りますか？

examples.en: Who the hell do you think you are?
examples.ja: 一体、あなたは自分をだれだと思ってるんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: Okay, so this one is really weird, sorry. Each of us only get <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>body</kanji> in our lifetimes, right? Well what <vocabulary>the heck</vocabulary>! What if I want more than one body. Let's all be mad about this together.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because いち is shortened to いっ here!

examples.en: "Thank you," I whispered.
examples.ja: 「ありがとう」と小声で言いました。

examples.en: The boy read his composition with a low voice.
examples.ja: 男の子は小声で自分の作文をよんだ。

examples.en: The teachers were talking very quietly.
examples.ja: 先生たちは小声ではなしていた。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>small</kanji> <kanji>voice</kanji> is so small that you can hardly hear it. It's a <vocabulary>low voice</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>whisper</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because, like in 大声, the こえ becomes ごえ thanks to our old friend rendaku.

examples.en: The color of Neptune is blue.
examples.ja: 海王星は色が青いです。

examples.en: Not much sun light reaches Neptune.
examples.ja: 海王星には日の光があまり行きません。

examples.en: Neptune was found on September 23, 1846.
examples.ja: 海王星は1846年9月23日に見つかりました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>ocean</kanji> <kanji>king</kanji>'s <kanji>star</kanji> is <vocabulary>Neptune</vocabulary>! If you know anything about Roman mythology this should be easy to remember!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Is there a used TV for 5,000 yen or under?
examples.ja: 五千円以下の中古のテレビはありますか？

examples.en: Squid a meter or less in length are small squid.
examples.ja: 一メートル以下のイカは小さいイカです。

examples.en: I heard it's free if you're twelve or younger!
examples.ja: 12才以下だとタダらしいよ！

examples.en: To think there's a work with a lower level of quality than this one… I'm shocked.
examples.ja: まさかこれ以下のレベルのクオリティの作品があるとは…ビックリです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Start <kanji>from</kanji> something and then go <kanji>below</kanji> it. Now you have "<vocabulary>no more than</vocabulary> ___," or, in other words, "___ <vocabulary>or less</vocabulary>!"

When used with numbers, 以下 always includes the number itself, like 十人以下 (ten or fewer people). In non-numerical contexts, it can mean "less than" in a looser sense, like お前は犬以下だ (You're less than a dog).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The townspeople go see the cherry blossoms together every year.
examples.ja: 町民は毎年みんなで花見に行く。

examples.en: Please let me and my husband join the townspeople's association.
examples.ja: ぜひ私と主人を町民の会に入れて下さい。

examples.en: I want to make it a lively town so that townspeople can live with peace of mind.
examples.ja: 町民が安心して生活できるように、活気ある町にしたいです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Town</kanji> <kanji>peoples</kanji> are the <vocabulary>townspeople</vocabulary>! This can also be singular, so a <vocabulary>townsperson</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The next class is next week.
examples.ja: 次のクラスは来週です。

examples.en: The theme of next week's composition is "the day I was born".
examples.ja: 来週の作文のテーマは「自分の生まれた日」です。

examples.en: I'm building up my stamina by running every day in preparation for next week's marathon.
examples.ja: 来週のマラソンのために、毎日走って体力をつけています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>next</kanji> <kanji>week</kanji> is the <vocabulary>next week</vocabulary>. It isn't last week or this week, it's the next one!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The diamond shines when the sun hits it.
examples.ja: 日が当たると、ダイアモンドは光る。

examples.en: The water in the pool shines with the sunlight.
examples.ja: プールの水が日の光でキラキラと光ります。

examples.en: Didn't the sky shine red just now?
examples.ja: 今、空が赤く光ったよね？

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>light</kanji> or <kanji>shine</kanji>, so the verb is <vocabulary>to shine</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to flash</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to glitter</vocabulary>. Just imagine what happens when something emits light!
reading_mnemonic: Remember how you learned the reading for 光? Well this is almost the same thing. Just change the り to る and you'll know this reading!

examples.en: From now on, please email this address.
examples.ja: 以後は、このアドレスにメールして下さい。

examples.en: I'll be careful after this.
examples.ja: 以後、気をつけます。

examples.en: After April 8th, you have to go to school.
examples.ja: 四月八日以後は、学校に行かなければいけません。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>From</kanji> <kanji>after</kanji>, just means <vocabulary>after this</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>from now on</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Loaves of bread are often sold in slices of six or eight.
examples.ja: 一斤のパンは6枚切りか8枚切りで売られていることが多い。

examples.en: I wonder if I can live off of one loaf bread until the end of the month.
examples.ja: たった一斤のパンで、月末までを生きていけるかな？

examples.en: I can live off of a loaf of bread and some Nutella.
examples.ja: パン一斤と、ニュテラがあれば生きていけるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>bread loaf counter</kanji> is counting <vocabulary>one loaf of bread</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the shortening though!

examples.en: This bread is 500 yen for two loaves.
examples.ja: このパンは、二斤で五百円です。

examples.en: I made two loaves for sandwiches, but it was still not enough.
examples.ja: サンドイッチ用のパンは二斤作ったけど、それでも足りませんでした。

examples.en: You can't eat two loaves in a day.
examples.ja: 一日で二斤は、さすがに食べることが出来ないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Two</kanji> <kanji>bread loaf counter</kanji>s are counting <vocabulary>two loaves of bread</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Does Mars have water?
examples.ja: 火星には水がありますか？

examples.en: I would like to go to Mars right now if possible.
examples.ja: できれば今すぐ火星に行きたいと思っています。

examples.en: Apparently, the sunset sky looks blue on Mars.
examples.ja: 火星の日の入りは空が青く見えるそうです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>fire</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji> is <vocabulary>Mars</vocabulary>. This should be easy to remember, because Mars is the only planet in our solar system that's the color of fire.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Have you ever seen Jupiter?
examples.ja: 木星を見たことありますか？

examples.en: What's between Mars and Jupiter?
examples.ja: 火星と木星のあいだには、何がありますか。

examples.en: Jupiter and Saturn were born like that.
examples.ja: 木星や土星はこうして生まれたんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>tree</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji> is the planet <vocabulary>Jupiter</vocabulary>. Imagine Jupiter covered in very strange trees — the kind that are able to take root in gas! It's a pretty weird image, but will hopefully help you to remember this word. Alternatively, think about how the clouds around Jupiter make patterns that look a lot like wood grain.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This town is close to human habitation.
examples.ja: この町は、人里に近い。

examples.en: There is a house in the mountain far from the village.
examples.ja: 人里からはなれた山に家が有ります。

examples.en: Sometimes, bears show up in villages.
examples.ja: 人里にクマが出てくることがある。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>person</kanji>'s <kanji>hometown</kanji> is a <vocabulary>human habitation</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>village</vocabulary>. This word has a slightly old-fashioned feel, and it's usually used for small villages in the countryside.

It's often combined with はなれた (separated) to talk about how far away from the nearest human habitation something is.
reading_mnemonic: This jukugo uses the kun'yomi of the kanji instead of the more usual on'yomi. You learned both of these readings when you learned the vocabulary 人 and 里. Just notice that さと becomes ざと, because of rendaku.

examples.en: It generally takes about two minutes.
examples.ja: 大体、二分くらいかかります。

examples.en: Shall we rest for fifteen minutes?
examples.ja: 十五分休みましょうか。

examples.en: It's about five minutes on foot from my apartment to a convenience store.
examples.ja: 私のアパートからコンビニまでは歩いて大体五分くらいです。

meaning_mnemonic: What's <kanji>part</kanji> of an hour? A <vocabulary>minute</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>minutes</vocabulary>! This word is the suffix version of 分, so it goes after numbers to say how many minutes, and is used for telling the time too.
reading_mnemonic: This uses a different on'yomi than what you learned with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember this reading: How many minutes of fun (ふん) will you have today? Lots and lots of minutes, I hope! Depending on the number before 分, its pronunciation can change to ぷん, because of rendaku. We're looking for the original reading ふん here though!

examples.en: This suit jacket doesn't have an inside pocket.
examples.ja: このスーツのジャケットには内ポケットがありません。

examples.en: This notebook fits into the inside pocket of a bag.
examples.ja: このノートは、バッグの内ポケットに入ります。

examples.en: Look, that kid's putting bugs in his inside pocket.
examples.ja: 見て、あの子、内ポケットに虫を入れてるよ！

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>inside</kanji> ポケット is your <vocabulary>inside pocket</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi for the kanji. You learned that reading when you learned the word 内.

examples.en: Today, we're going to learn about Napoleon The Third.
examples.ja: 今日は、ナポレオン三世について学びましょう。

examples.en: Napoleon III was born in the year 1808.
examples.ja: ナポレオン三世は1808年に生まれた。

examples.en: Napoleon Bonaparte is more famous than Napoleon III, isn't he?
examples.ja: ナポレオン・ボナパルトはナポレオン三世より有名ですよね。

meaning_mnemonic: Adding "third generation" to someone's name means that they are the third generation of people with that name. In this case, the person's name is ナポレオン (Napoleon), so this means <vocabulary>Napoleon The Third</vocabulary>, also written as <vocabulary>Napoleon III</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The kanji here are pronounced exactly the same as in the standalone word 三世. That is, it's a jukugo word which uses the on'yomi for both kanji.

examples.en: That person is famous.
examples.ja: その人、有名人だよ。

examples.en: I'm busy that day.
examples.ja: その日は、いそがしいんだ。

examples.en: At that moment, there was a loud boom.
examples.ja: そのとき、ドーンと大きな音がした。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how それ means "that one"? その has a very similar meaning: <vocabulary>that</vocabulary>. It's used before a noun that's either close to the person you're talking to, or fairly close to both of you. For example, その本 is "that book", and the book in question might be in the hand of the person you're talking to, or it might be on a shelf not far from you both.

examples.en: I think I've seen that person over there somewhere before.
examples.ja: あの人、どこかで見たことある気がする。

examples.en: Do you remember that day?
examples.ja: あの日のこと、おぼえてる？

examples.en: I should have said "thank you" at the time.
examples.ja: あのとき、「ありがとう」って言えばよかった。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how あれ means "that one over there"? Well, あの means <vocabulary>that</vocabulary>, and goes before a noun to point out something that is far away from both you and the person you're talking to, such as あの本 (that book over there) or あの子犬 (that puppy over there).

Notice how these words starting with あ are far away from you? We'll be learning a few more of these, and they all follow the same pattern! What's more, you’ll notice that words ending in の tend to go before a noun.

examples.en: New Year's is coming soon.
examples.ja: もうすぐ、お正月ですね。

examples.en: When does your New Year's holiday start?
examples.ja: 正月休みは、いつからですか？

examples.en: At this year's New Year sale, all the suits will be 50% off.
examples.ja: 今年の正月のセールでは、スーツが全て五十パーセントオフです。

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>correct</kanji> the <kanji>moon</kanji> because it's a <vocabulary>New Year</vocabulary>. It's the beginning of a fresh year, so you gotta have the moon in the correct position.

This usually refers to the first few days of a new year, and it's one of the biggest holidays in Japan.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Both of these kanji have a couple of on'yomi readings, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember which ones to use:

At <vocabulary>New Year</vocabulary>, you hate your <reading>Shou</reading>gun's <reading>guts</reading> (しょうがつ). He doesn't celebrate New Year, you see, so none of you get any time off. He even started a war last New Year and ruined everyone's holidays. No wonder you hate that shougun's guts.

examples.en: We're trying to figure out how to structure our next business.
examples.ja: 次のビジネスの仕組みを考えています。

examples.en: Do you know the inner workings of the world?
examples.ja: あなたは世の中の仕組みを知っていますか？

examples.en: If you press a button on this TV remote three times, it triggers a mechanism to unlock this door.
examples.ja: このテレビのリモコンのボタンを三回おすと、このドアがアンロックされる仕組みになっています。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Doing</kanji> something as a <kanji>group</kanji> requires a <vocabulary>system</vocabulary>. Without some sort of <vocabulary>structure</vocabulary>, everyone does their own thing, and you would never be able to get stuff done as a group, you know?

仕組み refers to the concept of a "mechanism" or "system." It includes the underlying structure, organization, or framework that governs how something works or operates, highlighting its logic, order, and other often unseen things.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a word with an irregular combination of readings. 仕 uses its on'yomi reading, and 組 uses its kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember this unusual combination:

To be more successful in doing group assignments, you came up with a <vocabulary>system</vocabulary> called "<reading>shee</reading>p <reading>cumi</reading>n (しくみ). Why "sheep cumin"? Sheep are known to be good team players (or herd players, should I say?), so you just sticked it to the name of the group you lead, the cumin group, hoping everyone can work together better, like sheep!

examples.en: The clownfish is a saltwater fish.
examples.ja: カクレクマノミは海水魚です。

examples.en: Which is the most popular saltwater fish in this store?
examples.ja: このお店で一番人気のある海水魚はどれですか？

examples.en: After all, I'm worried about the smell of saltwater fish.
examples.ja: やっぱり海水魚はニオイが気になります。

meaning_mnemonic:
You've got a <kanji>sea</kanji> <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>fish</kanji>, or in other words, a <vocabulary>saltwater fish</vocabulary>.

海水魚 refers to fish that live in the ocean, as opposed to freshwater fish.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: How is life in the northern country?
examples.ja: 北国のくらしはどうですか？

examples.en: Winter in the northern country is very long.
examples.ja: 北国の冬は、とても長いです。

examples.en: Children in the north are good at playing in the snow.
examples.ja: 北国の子どもたちは雪あそびが上手です。

meaning_mnemonic:
Go <kanji>north</kanji> into the <kanji>country</kanji>. Now you're in <vocabulary>northern country</vocabulary>.

北国 is used to describe northern regions where it gets all cold and snowy in winter, like Hokkaido or Tohoku in Japan or parts of Finland or Canada outside of Japan.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. Luckily they're readings you've already learned, so you're good to go here. Just watch out for the rendaku that changes くに to ぐに.

examples.en: The afternoon sun is so bright I can't see the TV.
examples.ja: 西日がまぶしくて、テレビが見えません。

examples.en: The setting sun made the curtains glow orange.
examples.ja: 西日でカーテンがオレンジ色に光りました。

examples.en: The afternoon sun is so strong that the sunroom is like a sauna.
examples.ja: 西日が強くて、サンルームがサウナみたいになっています。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>west</kanji> <kanji>sun</kanji> is, of course, the <vocabulary>afternoon sun</vocabulary>. 

西日 describes the sun when it's in the western part of the sky. It generally refers to the afternoon sun, but it can also mean the <vocabulary>setting sun</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>evening sun</vocabulary>. Basically, you can use it for sun or sunlight from mid-afternoon until sunset!
reading_mnemonic: This word uses kun'yomi readings for both 西 (にし) and 日 (ひ). You've seen these readings before, so if you can remember that they're kun'yomi then you're good to go! Just watch out for that rendaku that changes ひ to び.

examples.en: There are many mountains in East Asia.
examples.ja: 東アジアにはたくさんの山があります。

examples.en: Have you ever been to an East Asian country?
examples.ja: 東アジアの国に行ったことはありますか？

examples.en: In East Asia, there are many people who eat rice every day.
examples.ja: 東アジアでは、毎日お米を食べる人が多いです。

examples.en: East Asian food is delicious, but I gained weight from eating too much.
examples.ja: 東アジアのごはんはおいしいけど、食べすぎて太っちゃいました。

meaning_mnemonic: You have the kanji for <kanji>east</kanji> combined with アジア, the word for "Asia" — that makes this <vocabulary>East Asia</vocabulary>. Can you name all the countries in 東アジア?
reading_mnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi reading of 東, which you've already learned, so you should be good to go here!

examples.en: Ramadan will soon be over.
examples.ja: もうすぐラマダーンが明ける。

examples.en: In Japan, when the new year begins, people say "akemashite omedetou."
examples.ja: 日本では年が明けると「明けましておめでとう」って言うんだよ。

examples.en: That new shopping mall seems to get crowded on holidays. Should we go check it out around when Golden Week is over?
examples.ja: 新しくできたショッピングモール、休日は混んでるみたい。ゴールデンウィークが明けるころに行ってみない？

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>bright</kanji>, but the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to dawn</vocabulary>. It gets bright each morning when a new day dawns, so the connection kinda makes sense, right?

While 明ける is commonly used with 夜 to talk about the dawn breaking, it's also often used to talk about other time-related transitions. Because of this, it can mean <vocabulary>to end</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to begin</vocabulary> depending on the situation, as in 冬休みが明ける (winter vacation ends) or 年が明ける (the new year begins). Think of it like a new phase in your life is "dawning."
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, it's going to use the kun'yomi reading. In this case, that's あ — just like in 明かり — but since 明's kun'yomi readings can be a little irregular, here's a mnemonic to help you out:

When it starts <vocabulary>to dawn</vocabulary>, you gaze up at the sky and exclaim "<reading>ah</reading>" (あ)! The dawn sky is just so beautiful, and the crisp dawn air feels so fresh in your lungs, you can't help but sigh with delight: "ah!"
